captions.text: [TL;DR MUSIC]
[TUBA SAYS: DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA, DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA]
[TUBA & SYNTH SAY: DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA, DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA]
It's salty ears 66 from Utah USA asks, "Korean's seem to focus on age and respecting their elders
even if it's only a one year difference, does this make it difficult to make friends,
and have we made any mistake that make us seem disrespectful."
Okay, this is a really good question actually, definitely something you face a lot in Korea.
We've got this email tons of times. Yeah, so I think it really really depends on the Korean person.
Let's say you meet someone who's really interested in making foreigner friends,
and they're kind of already into foreign culture they'll totally scrap
the korean hierarchy of names, and age, and marriage and they'll just be like, right away,
"hey my name is mo mo mo = blah blah blah great to meet you."
But those are really the foreignized Koreans, the Korean people that have a lot of
experience with foreign people and they don't try to hold foreigners to Korean standards.
yeah, so maybe they lived overseas and they're gotten used to that already.
So with the Koreans that don't have a lot of experience with foreigners,
they will be noticeable uncomfortable when it comes to dealing with them,
and they will ask what's you age and what's your marital status
so that they can try and understand what position they should have with you.
yeah and a lot of foreigners that first come to korea might feel offended
we know some people that said things like, "oh that's weird why would you ask my age,
or why wouldn't you ask if I'm single or married?"
But they're not at all trying to be offensive,
it's just how Korean society works so they can know what to say to you,
how to address you, and so on an so forth.  Noe because this is a little bit confusing,
we actually found a really helpful video on this by Dr. Whathexherfrigginame.
[static sound]
Is it filming? Is it on? I don't like these--it's filming--it's filming? *clears throat*
[snobby university music]
Hello, I am Dr.Whathehexherfrigginame and today we will talk about honorific,
and honorific name systems in the Korean culture.
Learning the correct honorific name to call your Korean friends can be STRESSFUL!
But I shall break it down for you and make it easier for you to understand.
Rollllll the fiiiiilm!!!
So, first, if you meet someone who is in school with you,
the person who is a grade above you, he is called your "seonbae"
and it's doesn't matter if you are boy or girl, this is gender neutral.
Since you're younger then them, you are their junior,
and they will describe you as their "hubae".
We saw this being used a lot in the drama Boys Before Flowers between Geum Jandi and Jihoo.
---HEY! YOU! STOP DREAMING ABOUT THE FLOWER BOYZ! AND PAY ATTENTION TO ME!
But let's say you go out and "talk a lot" and you drink soju and beer and these kind of things,
if you become closer friends, your Seonbae might not feel uncomfortable
being called "seonbae" all the time since it represents both an age gap
and authority over the other person.
In that case, they can change their honorific label to one that represents closeness,
but still maintains the age divide. For example between girls:
Seonbae to hubae, but when they get closer, she says, "EH! Call me Eunnie"
Between guys when they get closer, he might say, "hey, call me Hyeung"
Between older girl and younger guy, she might say call me "Noona"
Between the older guy and younger girl he might say call me "Oppa".
So you can see between the age gap there is always an implicit barrier
reminding you that you can never really be BFFs.
Now I hope you can understand the importance of the Korean label system.
Now let's continue on to my next lecture, the importance between Geum Jandi, Jihoooo
and their relationship between Goo Jun Pyo and his curly hair. He's so dreamy---
[sleeping nap time music]
[snoring]
[RECORD SCRATCH, MUSIC STOPS] HUH! WHAT!? is it over? Huh?
That girl is so boring. Uh. That was a long video. She's pretty though.
She's got a moustache, she's not pretty at all, you take that back.
I like her.
*GASP*
[TL;DR MUSIC STARTS UP AGAIN]
So the whole honorific name thing is usually broken down
specifically to do with age, and position in a company.
Those are like the two big ones I think, right?
But it's not only for naming people,
it's also for how you're supposed to interact with that person as a result.
Mmmmm...especially with drinking.
So as soon as you know that person's age,
you know exactly what you should be doing with them.
So it was my first couple weeks in Korea, and we were going for TEAM BUILDING EXERCISE (hweshik).
And TEAM BUILDING EXERCISE (hweshik) is usually when your whole staff goes out for supper together
and it's supposed to be like a bonding experience,
it's not like a meeting or anything.
TEAM BUILDING EXERCISE 99!
It was my first time meeting my principal face to face at dinner,
and he wanted me to sit across from him,
and so I was a little bit nervous and flustered
but I had read so many books about Korean culture before coming here,
So when he poured me soju, because he's older than me,
and he's my principal I should be super respectful,
So I made sure to hold my cup either with two hands or supporting it at the bottom.
You have to show that kind of respect,
And everyone was impressed, they were like OHHHH MARTINA KNOWS!
And right away I took the bottle, and I poured his glass,
because you should do back and forth like that
And everyone was like, WHOA MARTINA KNOWS!
And then the big bomb came,
So everyone was like ONE SHOT!  And everyone started to turn away from the principal,
But I just took the shot straight, staring at him, you know, like
[COWBOY WESTERN MUSIC STARTS] WHUTCHA GONNA DO, BOY?
I'MA DRINK THIS SOJU AND THEN I'MA SHOOT YOU IN THE FACE
I felt like a cowboy, you know, staring him down or something,
[COWBOY MUSIC ENDS]
And then she murdered her principal which made her relationship with her school
a whole lot more awkward for her.
THAT DIDN'T HAPPEN!
[TL;DR MUSIC STARTS]
The principal didn't say anything.  He was such a cool guy.
And they were really impressed that I already knew all the other things,
but I asked my coworkers like "GUISE WHY DID EVERYONE TURN AWAY?!"
But they said that you should show respect to your elders
or people in higher positions by turning away when you drink,
So if you're the principal, I should have turned away like this,
or like covering my mouth like this.
But put yourself in this situation. Say you have the principal in front of you,
the Vice Principal to the left of you, and the head teacher to the right of you,
then where do you drink? SO, what you should do, is turn all the way around,
and then you can drink.  What happens if an old man sneaks up behind you. *LOLS*
Another similar story I have, I remember we were dealing with some Korean associates
and we had drank a lot of soju, and whenever you drink a shot you usually clink it
and you take a shot.  What I did by accident was, when I clinked it,
my glass was higher then his, and he wasn't very upset about it,
but he corrected me afterwards.  He said that my glass should never be above his
because he is older.  It should either be below his or on the same level.
I wanted to say to him, look I already had like 12 of these glasses,
my motor skills are really not that good right now.
You're lucky that this shot glass didn't go directly into your face.
So you should be happy that we were at least able to touch glasses somehow.
But Koreans are really good at drinking. Yes they are. We're light weights.
So long story short, it is possible to make friends with different people
from different ages in Korea, but a lot of the time it's awkward for some people
because they know that there are different rituals you have to do with different ages.
I think that those rituals and those respect things can kind of remind you
that you're not on the same level, like I have to respect you because you're older that me
and it's kind of hard to become BFFs with someone in that situation.
BUt don't let it scare you away, my best friend in Korea is at least 5 years older than me,
YEAH SEOKBOK! And she said if I called her Ahjumma..she's kill me. Oh. Ohh.
So that's it for this week's TL;DR, if there is a question you want us to answer
for next week's TL;DR, leave you question in google moderator page.
Or, you can check out the questions already asked
and you can thumb them up, or thumb them down.
[GONG!!]
[SEXY HUMPING MUSIC]

comments.text:
+littlemissmello It may also depend on individuals. f(x)'s Luna, who is the 
younger-by-minutes of twins, once claimed in an interview for the "Red 
Light" promotion that her sister insists on the honorific when they 
interact. I don't know if she was joking or dead serious, I'm trending 
towards the latter, however. 

My guess would be, you don't have to volunteer the information, but if your 
sister was present and chose to exert that influence (slight as as it may 
be), you would be obliged to let her.
comments.author: Gary Cone

comments.text:
+Charla Lala No not at all :) In Korea everyone ages at the same moment on 
new year's day. So my friend and I are both born in 1993 but she's born in 
October and I in November but because we're born in the same year we're the 
same age (even in the month where she already had her actual birthday and I 
haven't). She and I are chingu (same aged friends). However we share a 
mutual friend who's born in March 1994 and she'd have to call us eonni even 
when her birthday passed and she's in western terms the same age.Age works 
a lot differently in Korea. When I first started learning Korean I met this 
Korean guy and he told me he was 21, just like me, and I was like "that's 
cool, we're chingu!" but later I found out he was the same age as my 
younger brother XD He was born in 1995. In Korea you are 1 year old 
immediately when you get born. Then, even though everyone has a birthday, 
everyone ages one year on new year's day. So imagine being born on December 
31st: you'd already be two years old after having lived only a day!
comments.author: littlemissmello

comments.author: Pat Shiver

comments.text:
Ok, while I already know the Korean basic honorifics which I can somewhat 
compare with Japanese honorifics for easier learning. For example (using 
whatever that was shown in the video):

Seonbae = Senpai
Hubae = Kouhai
Eonni & noona can be like nee-san while hyeong & oppa can be like nii-san 
but with the fact that the person being addressed is not related to you by 
blood.

So I have a few questions.

1. How would the senior address the junior if they're close together? Or is 
there like no form for that all? The only thing I came across would be 
dongsaeng which is gender neutral. However, it's not like... Let's use an 
example. Let's say JiYong-oppa to DaeSung-oppa (yes, they're both older 
than me). It's not like JiYong-oppa is gonna address DaeSung-oppa as 
"DaeSung-dongsaeng". So yeah, that was my question.

2. How would two people who are of the same age but within a few months 
difference address each other when they're close? Do they still go with the 
basic honorifics like in the video or do they have a specific way of it or 
there's none at all? Let's take another example. JiYong-oppa and 
YeongBae-oppa are the same age but the latter is a few months older. Since 
they're close together, how would YeongBae-oppa address JiYong-oppa in a 
casual but close manner?﻿
comments.author: D-Walker

comments.text:
If you're close together, the younger might use casual honorifics, but 
usually close friends don't use honorifics at all, they just call them by 
name. My mom and her best friend of over 20 years are almost a year apart 
and they don't use honorifics at all. Ever. I have never heard them use 
honorifics to each other.

comments.text:
What's the difference between American Age and Korean Age? Why are they 
different? I hear some ppl say they are a different age in America vs 
Korea, but I don't understand that. ﻿
comments.author: Sarah Kupka

comments.text:
Koreans are a year old when they are born, and everyone gets a year older 
at the same time, that being New Years. No exceptions. Your birthday 
celebrates your birth, not you getting older. Even if you're born on New 
Years Eve, you will turn 2 the next day.
comments.author: Brandon Kim

comments.text: oh i understand that now ! it's so interesting
comments.author: Selma Rizvic

comments.text:
The idea is that in the traditional Asian way, the nine months spent in the 
womb is counted towards your age (and usually rounded up to a year). In 
this traditional Asian system, new year's day (the lunar new year) is when 
people are considered a year older, instead of their birthdays. Also, if 
someone is born in a certain part of the year (I think it's before the 
lunar new year, but I'm not sure), his/her traditional Asian age can be two 
years older than his/her western culture age. Due to globalization, Asians 
are quite aware of western age counting and keep track of it personally and 
in official records, but may forget to use it when talking to foreigners.

(I say Asian and not specifically Korean because I was first taught about 
this from my parents when I was little, who knew this as being a Chinese 
thing. I think other Asians who follow the lunar new year did age like 
this, too. Note that Japanese don't follow the lunar new year, though I'd 
bet they did a few hundred years ago.)
comments.author: chaowalker

comments.author: Bethany Lingle

comments.text:
Oppa and Eonni are used by GIRLS to address older guys(Oppa) and older 
girls(Eonni). Hyung and Noona are used by GUYS to address older guys(Hyung) 
and older girls(Noona).
comments.author: Brandon Kim

comments.text:
You can ask if you may call people these sibling honorifics, but the more 
socially acceptable thing to do is wait for them to offer because it 
signifies closeness through a lower level of respect, so the junior should 
not initiate this. A student should definitely not call a teacher one of 
the sibling honorifics; the word for "teacher" is much more revered and 
applied to non-teachers who have a position that is respected. The only 
exceptions I've seen are when it's non-formal anyway, like a star 
addressing a much older fan who would like to be thought of as young enough 
for a sibling honorific to be used. Sunbaenim is a more polite way to say 
sunbae (sunbae and seonbae are different romanizations of the same Hangul) 
and the "nim" just means you're showing more respect.

I'm sorry I can't answer how youths should refer to adults, mr./mrs. 
specifics, or ahjusshi and ahjumma. All I know is that most people don't 
think of flattering things when they hear "ahjumma" (they usually think of 
women who are old, loud, stingy, and rude), so most women hate being called 
ahjumma, even if they fit the textbook description.
comments.author: chaowalker

comments.text: What do Koreans think about Indians?﻿
comments.author: Ashna Alex

comments.text: The names really confuse me ﻿
comments.author: Amber Bostwick

comments.text: +chaowalker ok, I see now! Thank you so much for your very useful answer ^^
comments.author: Alexandra Silah

comments.text:
+Alexandra Silah "Hubae" is not usually used for *addressing* someone. 
"Hubae" is for talking about/labeling someone. The same goes for 
"dongsaeng" (gender neutral word for "younger sibling"). There are much 
fewer rules for older people, so they can choose to call the younger and 
same-aged people by their given name. If they've already become close, an 
older/same-aged speaker can drop the medium-formal honorific "ssi" 
(pronounced like sshi). Adding a "ya" or "a" to the end of someone's name 
when calling out to them is quite *disrespectful when addressing someone 
older,* but acceptable and normal when addressing someone younger/same-aged 
and close (someone whom you can speak casually/impolitely with). Add "a" 
("ah") for someone whose name ends in a consonant and "ya" is for names 
that end in a vowel (these are like *casual* honorifics). Addressing 
someone with "ya" by itself is like saying "Hey, you!" and is still rude, 
even when speaking to someone younger, so only do it if you mean to scold 
someone lower ranking than you.
comments.author: chaowalker

comments.text:
+chaowalker hello! Since you've already answered some questions, would you 
mind telling me how older peoble call youger people? Like for example, a 
junior can call a senior friend "hyung" when they get close, but does the 
"hyung" still call his junior friend "hubae"? And for girls, from "unni" or 
"noona" to a junior? And "oppas"? I'm so curious.
comments.author: Alexandra Silah

comments.text:
+StoNedMunKee I don't know of a plural form of seonbae, but you can add nim 
at the end to make it more polite. The title seonbae-nim refers to people 
above you in your… line of rank (I don't know how to phrase this), but when 
I said "senior," I didn't mean "senior citizen"; it's only like someone who 
is a little ahead of you (like someone who has been in the same 
school/work/club system before you started).

However, if you're addressing someone who is in an entire grouping above 
you, you should call him/her *seonsaeng-nim* (*선생님*; 3 syllables: seon like 
in seonbae, saeng which sounds like sehng and nim), which is often 
translated as "teacher"/"professor", but can be used for most occupations 
that are well-respected, such as doctor, or a master in his/her field. A 
priest probably has his own title, but I don't know it, or any 
church-specific titles.

(Note: I use the "Revised Romanization" system of romanization for its 
consistency. Plenty of other people use older systems (Simon and Martina 
combine romanization systems in this video in their spelling of "noona" and 
"oppa" which would be "nuna" and "obba" in Revised Romanization), so you 
may see words spelled differently, but *mean the same thing and are 
supposed to be pronounced the same way*, even though another romanization 
system might use the same letters to mean different Hangeul and sounds.)
comments.author: chaowalker

comments.text:
+chaowalker You seem knowledgeable. What's the plural form of seonbae? Is 
there an even more respectable way of saying it? I occasionally go to a 
nearby Korean church on Sundays when I can make it there, and can really 
use this this Sunday. Thanks.
comments.author: StoNedMunKee

comments.text:
You mean the honorifics? I found it more confusing when people gave a lot 
of specifics, so the barebones listing is this:

Gender neutral & more formal:
Seonbae = senior
Hubae = junior

Female perspective:
Eonni = older sister
Obba = older brother

Male perspective:
Nuna = older sister
Hyeong = older brother

comments.author: Adrianne Kam

comments.text:
+Adrianne Kam No, the reason why it's weird is because in Korea everyone 
ages a year on the same day (new year's day) so people wouldn't consider 
themselves older or younger unless they're literally born in a different 
year (even if the one is born December 31st 1990 and the other is born 
January 1st 1991). I had to call a boy that was, to our western standards, 
just two months older than me but born in 1992, oppa while his younger 
brother didn't have to call me noona even though we differed almost exactly 
11 months, because he was born in 1993 just like. Weird because I'm a lot 
closer in age to that oppa than I was to that chingu.
comments.author: littlemissmello

comments.text:
This is a good question for America too. I had this situation recently. I 
think if you are at work and they are senior to you, you have to treat them 
with the respect of any senior even if they are your junior technically in 
years. That doesn't mean you need to grovel or act in an undignified way 
though. How they treat their unusual seniority thereafter is their own 
choice and you won't be on the line since you did the right thing. :)

comments.author: Royals

comments.text:
Near by 1year. Korean peoples ignore month or date at age generally. In 
korea, when you born, your age is 1. And January 1 in next year, you grow 
an year older.
In short, korean people's age is started at 1. Not 0. Also every korean 
peoples get older at same time: january 1. korean peoples call it 'korean 
age(한국나이)' or 'age(살)'. It marks that who is older and who is younger. But 
about identity, koreans use 'full age(만 ~세)' it is same to foreign age.

name/nickname.

comments.text:
Okay so let's say I went Korea and I met someone born the same year as me 
and we became friends. I am a few months older than them by American 
standards but in Korea they would be like a year older than me because of 
how they do their age system. In reality (or at least my reality), I should 
be older than them. Can someone please help me cause I'm so confused on 
what I'd do! ﻿
comments.author: The Ash Tenshi

comments.text:
+Q Bong Lee
i thought that if your born before that year's lunar new year, you will be 
another year older on that day, so than they will add two years if you were 
born after the lunar new year, they just add that one year, i don't know if 
it's right but i read it somewhere and it seems logic ;)
comments.author: Gwen BabyShawol

comments.text: Oh thank you! That makes a lot more sense now!
comments.author: The Ash Tenshi

comments.text:
if you are born in the same year you are equal.  if you are born in 
december the year before, and they are born in january the year after, you 
are older.  but to simplify, if you are born in same year, you are their 
age as well. so add one year to your own North American Age when you want 
to know your Korean Age. but sometimes i get confused too cause sometimes 
they add 2 years, which is really weird...(and i'm korean and i dunno...)
